newsitem.title: ITALY: Italian dairy farmers block roads to Milan airport.
newsitem.headline: Italian dairy farmers block roads to Milan airport.

text.p: Italian farmers blocked streets leading to Milan's Linate airport with tractors and cows on Saturday, protesting at a draft law they say does not compensate them enough for milk output cuts imposed by the European Union.
"People are calling us from all over Italy, wanting to take part in the protest...people keep arriving," protest leader Aldo Bettinelli told reporters.
More than 1,000 farmers took part in the demonstrations, forcing air passengers coming from the centre of the city to walk three km (two miles) to reach the international airport.
It was the third day of protests in the northern Italian city and the second day running that Milan's main airport was blocked.
Dairy farmers are protesting at a government draft law drawn up to establish compensatiion in the wake of tough EU quotas.

They said the bill fell short of their demands for the state to help bear the burden of EU "super levy" fines for overproduction. The farmers were due to discuss the matter with Agriculture Ministry officials later on Saturday.
Media reports say Italian farmers face 420 billion lire ($270 million) in EU fines for overproduction. Estimates from member states place Italy as the worst offender for exceeding its national quota.
Late last year, an EU Commission official said milk production in the 15-member bloc was 1.1 million tonnes over quota, with Italy accounting for 470,000 tonnes, nearly half.
The fines hit individual farmers and not the state. Farmers want the government to ensure that they do not have to shoulder the full burden themselves.
